On 2002-05-11 at 11:44 Berin Loritsch wrote:

>> From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...] 
>> 
>> Berin Loritsch wrote:
>> 
>> >I was writing a testcase, and realized that with all the assertion 
>> >methods in junit.framework.Assert, there is no assertEquals(double,

>> >double). There
>> >are versions for integers, longs, shorts, chars, Obejcts, 
>> etc.  Is this
>> >just
>> >an oversight?
>> >
>> 
>> It's in there as:
>> 
>>     assertEquals(double expected, double actual, double delta);
>
>
>Ah!
>
>I was wanting to use it like:
>
>      assertEquals(double expected, double actual);

Floating-point are messed up. The above method makes a claim about
precision that Java can't live up to. In the spirit of not promising
more than you can deliver, it's best not to use such a method. You can
always use a tolerance of 0, but be aware that it's not necessarily a
good idea.

Oh, and if you're not doing calculations with the double values, then
why are they doubles? A BigDecimal has the added advantage of not
succumbing to the same precision problems. Maybe even a String would
do. (I hate having to hack around the language's inadequacies, but it's
a living.)

>Or would that be assertSame()?

That's only for Object identity: true if two Objects are the same part
of memory; false otherwise.

>The thing is I was testing to see if the value I put into a class was
>the same I got out of a class.  There were no calculations at this
>point,
>where we would need to worry about the "delta" or +/- uncertainty.

Then a delta of 0 would be fine. It makes it clear that you're not
expecting rounding errors to enter into the mix. That communicates
something useful.

>BTW, is there something where we can easily test asymetrical
>uncertainties?
>You know, something along the lines of +.5/-.1 ?

Not built in to JUnit, but it's easy enough to build...

assertWithinRange(final double expected, final double actual, final
double upperTolerance, final double lowerTolerance) {
    assertTrue( actual >= expected - lowerTolerance && actual <=
expected + upperTolerance);
}
